name: Dwarf Mongoose
description: It has a compact body, short snout, small ear flaps, and relatively short legs. The fur is brown, gray, or reddish.
food_note: Invertebrates, eggs, tubers, or fallen fruits
image_alt: Dwarf Mongoose, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 18–26 cm; tail length 12–20 cm; average weight 275 g
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 49–56 days and bear 2–4 young
attractions: They form family groups of up to 20 individuals. They are active during the day, foraging for food. The group is led by a dominant female, the only one to breed with her mate. She gives birth up to three times per season, and the young initially hide in burrows, with group members bringing them food.
breeding: A single male appeared between 1971–1979, but regular breeding began in 2004. That year, six mongooses arrived from the wild, and two females from this group still live at the zoo.
